folder: Hell Gate Bridge, New York, N.Y.
text:
The newest bridge across the East River, New York City
This 1,000 foot span, the longest arch in the world, is over the dangerous channel at Hell Gate. Long Island City (a part of greater New York) is on the right of the picture, with Ward's Island on the left. The structure turns, crosses the island, passes over water again to Randall's Island and finally reaches the mainland in the Borough of the Bronx. It is wholly a railroad bridge, part of a six mile road connecting the Pennsylvania and New Haven Systems and permitting through freight and passenger service between New England and the South. The structure was formally dedicated on March 9, took four years to build and cost $27,000,000. It makes the fifth bridge across the East River all except the Brooklyn Bridge have been opened in the last twelve years.

April, 1917
American Press Assn.
title: Bridges - Hell Gate Bridge - [East River.]

folder: Ward's Island, New York, N.Y.
text:
Wards and Randalls Islands as viewed in a northwestward direction from above the Queens shore of the East River. Beyond same are the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx, divided by the Harlem River. This water-way also separates the islands from the Harlem sector of Manhattan. Note in the far distance the North (Hudson) River and the Jersey Palisades. At the right margin appears the Hellgate Bridge of the New York Central Railroad. Today (1938), the modern Triborough Bridge parallels this structure, connecting the two boroughs and the two islands.

January 7, 1922.

Dr. M.B. Stegman
Gift of Dr. Gustave Schoeler
title: Islands - Ward's and Randall's Islands.

folder: Sheridan Avenue & 158th Street (East), Bronx, NY
text:
Sheridan Ave. (foreground, left to right), south from East 161st to East 158th Streets, showing, extending east to Morris Ave. and south to East 153rd Street, the Melrose yard of the New York Central Railroad. Also shown is a panoramic view southeastward with the Hell Gate Bridge across the East River discernible in the distant right background. The point of vantage is the 10-story Concourse Plaza, at the N.E. corner of Grand Concourse and East 161st Street.

May 1926.

Brown Brothers.

folder: Ward's Island, New York, N.Y.
text:
Male inmates of the Insane Asylum, Ward's Island, undergoing Calisthenics; a daily routine thereon. Hell Gate Bridge may be seen dimly in the left background.

About 1928.
title: Islands - Ward's Island - Asylum inmates.

folder: Hell Gate Bridge, New York, N.Y.
text:
Hell Gate Bridge, showing the approach from the Bronx, spanning Ward's Island, with the Queensborough end at the right. The bridge is the rail link between the Penn. R.R. Terminal in Manhattan and the New England lines. The main span of the Bridge is 1016 ft. long and 300 ft. above high water mark. The cost of the bridge was $25,000,000.

About 1930.

Ewing Galloway.
title: Bridges - Hell Gate Bridge - [Bronx - Queensborough.]

folder: 9th Street & 26th Avenue, Queens, NY
text:
9th Street, north from 26th Avenue toward the East River, showing the United States Volunteer Life Saving Station at the foot of the street and the Tisdale Lumber Company's yard. In the background is the Hellgate Bridge. The Clark and Flagg kid leather works formely (1891) stood on the east side of the street (right). 4th Street, here, was known as Wardell Street.

P. L. Sperr
March 13, 1931

folder: Hell Gate Bridge, New York, N.Y.
text:
Ne. 1
Mid-town Manhattan skyline, framed in the Hell Gate Bridge with Oueens on the left and Wards Island to the right. The view is south fram the Shore Diive in Astoria, and shows this railread structure spanning the easterly channel ef the East River.

March 23, 1932
P. L. Sperr

No. 2
Another view, at a latter date, in the oppesite direction and showing in addition the newly constructed Triboro Bridge. The photographers vantage point here is the jutting peninsula in Astoria and he is viewing northward across Pot Cove. To the right is the Shere Drive and Astoria Park.

July 1, 1937
P. L. Sperr
title: Bridges - Hell Gate Bridge - [Queens].

text:
A general view northeastward for the 70 storied R.C.A. Building at Rockefeller Plaza, showing the midtown East Side - Yorkville - Lower Harlem districts of Manhattan bordering on the East River. In the mid ground are the white units that comprise the New York Hospital and Cornell University Medical College Center. Beyond appears the Borough of Queens, the Hellgate Bridge and the Long Island Sound.

August 9, 1933
Views 1, 2 and 3

P. L. Sperr

folder: Hell Gate Bridge, New York, N.Y.
text:
(1)
Hell Gate Bridge spans the notorious channel, called Hell Gate; at the convergance of Long Island Sound and the East River. The seething whirlpools and conflicting currents, made it extremely unnavigable; sinking many vessels, and drowning innumerable men: hence the name. The bridge begins at Port Morris in the Bronx, spanning Ward's and Randall's Islands, to Astoria in Queens. It is one of the classics of modern achievement, being the world's longest continued span. The eastern railway interests combined to build it, and completed it in 1917.

July 25, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
Same, over Ward's Island.
July 25, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
Same.
July 25, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Bridges - Hell Gate Bridge - [The bridge begins at Port Norris, Bronx, spanning Ward's and Randall's Islands, to Astoria, Queens.]

folder: Hell Gate Bridge, New York, N.Y.
text:
The New York Connecting Railway Bridge (Hellgate Bridge) as photographed southwestward from Astoria. Wards Island provides a base for the underpinning shown.

Alexander Alland

This photo is one of a series that appeared in the published volume "Portrait of N. Y." by Felix Reisenberg and Alex. Alland, IRGV.

1939
title: Bridges - Hell Gate Bridge [New York Connecting Railroad Bridge.]

folder: Manhattan - [Hell Gate and Triborough  Bridges.], Manhattan, NY
text:
River Scenes--Manhattan: A tugboat on the upper East River, silhouetted against the Hellgate and Triboro Bridges. The Astoria shoreline is on the left; while Manhattan is on the right.

1939

Alexander Alland
title: East River - River scenes - Manhattan - [Hell Gate and Triborough Bridges.]
